criteria: Understanding the Relationship Between Intersections and Solutions
Finding Solutions Using Tables of Values
descriptions: Student does not demonstrate an understanding of how the intersection points of two graphs relate to the solutions of an equation.
Student shows limited understanding, struggling to connect intersection points to solutions or explain the underlying principle.
Student can identify intersection points on a graph but has difficulty explaining their significance as solutions to the equation f(x) = g(x).
Student understands that intersection points represent solutions but may struggle to articulate the reasoning clearly or apply it to different types of functions.
Student clearly explains that the x-coordinates of intersection points are the solutions to f(x) = g(x) and demonstrates this understanding with linear and polynomial functions.

Student provides a thorough explanation of why intersection points yield solutions, applying this knowledge effectively to linear, polynomial, rational, absolute value, exponential, and logarithmic functions.
Student is unable to use technology to graph functions or find intersection points.
Student attempts to use technology but struggles to graph the functions correctly or identify intersection points.
Student can graph functions using technology but has difficulty accurately determining the coordinates of intersection points.
Student can use technology to find intersection points but requires guidance to interpret these points as solutions.
Student independently uses technology to graph functions and accurately identify intersection points, relating them to the solutions of the equation.
Student expertly uses technology to graph complex functions, accurately finds intersection points, interprets them as solutions, and explains the process clearly and efficiently.
Student does not attempt to use tables of values to approximate solutions or cannot create appropriate tables.
Student creates tables of values but struggles to identify approximate solutions from the data.
Student can identify approximate solutions from tables of values but has difficulty explaining the level of accuracy.
Student uses tables of values to find approximate solutions, demonstrating understanding of the method, but may have some inaccuracies.
Student accurately uses tables of values to approximate solutions and explains the limitations of this method in terms of precision.
Student skillfully uses tables of values to find successive approximations, demonstrating a deep understanding of the method's strengths and limitations, and communicates the results effectively.
